body_html: If we add reading all frames (which I think would be great, it's the main use of the gif format these days after all), the output should simply be a 4D tensor [frames, height, width, channels]. In case the gif has only a single image, the output would be [1, height, width, channels]. This is different from the decode_jpg, and decode_png functions, but we can provide a Python convenience function decode_single_frame_gif or similar which collapses the first dimension.
body_text: If we add reading all frames (which I think would be great, it's the main use of the gif format these days after all), the output should simply be a 4D tensor [frames, height, width, channels]. In case the gif has only a single image, the output would be [1, height, width, channels]. This is different from the decode_jpg, and decode_png functions, but we can provide a Python convenience function decode_single_frame_gif or similar which collapses the first dimension.
body: If we add reading all frames (which I think would be great, it's the main use of the gif format these days after all), the output should simply be a 4D tensor `[frames, height, width, channels]`. In case the gif has only a single image, the output would be `[1, height, width, channels]`. This is different from the `decode_jpg`, and `decode_png` functions, but we can provide a Python convenience function `decode_single_frame_gif` or similar which collapses the first dimension.
